country:
None
text:
Ok, like many others I, too, used JellyBean14's changes.  They are as follows: 
"(1) add salt, pepper, and garlic, (2) double the sauce but keep the cream cheese and worcestershire the same,(3) use Golden Mushroom, not Cream of Mushroom or don't make this at all, (4) reduce the cooking time to about 5-6 hours on low, (5) add a "dollup" of sour cream when you add the cream cheese to get an extra "tang", (6) add a bullion cube, (7) add a half packet of onion soup mix, (8) serve over egg noodles, (9) add sauteed mushrooms about 1/2 an hour before"
I did not add the mushrooms nor the sour cream.  My family ate it, but didn't rush for seconds.  In my opinion it was WAY too salty... and I love salt.  Next time I will find ways to cut back on the sodium some how.  Mine cooked on high for 2 hours then low for 2 1/2 hour and the meat was perfectly tender.  I'll try again...

text:
I used some of the tips from the other reviews: (1) add salt, pepper, (2) double the sauce but keep the cream cheese and worcestershire the same, (3) add a bullion cube, (7) add a half packet of onion soup mix.  I used regular cream of mushroom and cooked for about 9 hours on low and it turned out fine.  Next time, I won't add as much salt.  I probably put in about a teaspoon and that seemed to be a little too much.  Between the onion soup mix and the boullion cube, it doesn't need much more salt.  Otherwise, this a great recipe.  Easy to prepare and tastes great.  What more can you ask for out of recipe?

Pretty Good!  Required little effort, yet yummy!  I used the cream of mushroom soup as many others did.  I also added about 2/3 cup of additional water b/c it didn't seem like enough liquid to let it go the whole day.  I DID end up thickening it with a little cornstarch... I also added garlic powder and pepper to the mix.  It fed my family of four + leftovers for lunch for today!(mixed in cooked egg noodles b/f serving. We had a vege and salad as well).  I think I will make this again and keep experimenting!

Although I thought this recipe was "passable" my sister didn't like it. With the cream cheese, she said she felt as if she was eating a dip. I'm confused as to how this recipe is supposed to yield 4 servings because it was only enough to feed my sister and my husband. I will stick to Daria's Slow Cooker Beef Stroganoff on this site. It does take a little more work than this recipe but it's so worth it.

text:
This isn't what I remember as a kid.  For some reason, my mom's was always much creamier.  This recipe is very small on portions and was starting to burn on low in my crock pot, so I had to turn the crock pot down to warm and when I added the cream cheese I turned the heat back up, but it just wouldn't blend.  We had chunks of cream cheese floating through it, kinda gross.  It was also VERY salty, despite not adding any extra salt.  I followed the recipe exactly and it just did not remind me at all of the rich, creamy stroganoff I had as a kid.  I won't be making this one again.

text:
Loved it. I tripled it for 2 adults and 3 kids. There's enough leftovers for everyone. I used 2 golden mushroom's and 1 regular cream of mushroom(it's a little cheaper). I added a boullion cube to the water also. I also used sirloin steak because it was on sale. There was way more gravy than meat so I will add more meat next time. I had to let the cream cheese sit for about 15 mins to melt in the gravy because it looked lumpy. Overall a very easy recipe because you don't need to pre-cook the meat.

text:
Have been making this recipe for months. I like to use cream of wild mushroom soup instead. It is also made in a beef broth  and the one time I used golden mushroom I didn't like it so well. I also add some garlic powder, fresh cracked pepper, a beef boullion cube dissolved in the waterusually about 1tbsp of onion soup mix and a big spoon of sour cream at the end with the cream cheese. We always serve it over egg noodles.  I have shared this recipe with many and everyone like it save one who thought it to rich. In that case I say take out the cream cheese.

text:
I made this twice and the second time I browned the beef and onions first.  I think that was a little nicer flavor, but I also added pepper and used white wine instead of the water.  Finally, I used cream cheese and sour cream.  I made this for a dinner party and wanted it very easy, so the recipe was quadrupled in a 6 Qt. slow cooker.  About 1/2 before serving I also added a bag and a half of egg noodles.  It soaked up too much of the juice, so I kept adding water to it.  I think if I had made extra sauce from the beginning and used only one bag of noodles it would have been perfect.

text:
3/29/06-I really liked this sauce but I was kinda turned off by the texture of the stew meat. I think I'll try some sliced flank steak next time instead. I used 2 cans of soup (didn't have golden mushroom so I used cream of mushroom w/ roasted garlic), added a beef bouillion cube, added a cup of white wine & in the last hour of cooking I added a can of sliced mushrooms...I let the cream cheese come to room temp before adding & it melded perfectly. And I only cooked on low for 5 hours...the stew meat was literally falling apart. Served it over egg noodles w/ a side of frozen corn, cukes marinated in salt & sugar & their own juices & croissants.UPDATE 6/08/06---I did make this again using sliced round steak. This time I seared the meat first before adding to crockpot but otherwise cooked as I did last time. I liked the texture of the sliced round steak MUCH better!

text:
Fantastic result!  As I put the ingredients together in the crock pot, I found myself thinking that this was going to be really boring.  That may or may not be true, but I won't ever know due to my additions.  I tripled the sauce and to it added a small can of medium-hot diced green chiles.  It still didn't seem to be exciting enough, so I added 3 T. of *hot* green chile sauce.  At the end, I doubled the cream cheese, not tripled.  My sons both exclaimed *immediately*, "this gets 5 stars!"  My husband was so busy eating (which told me all I needed to know) that he didn't say anything about it until he was done:  "I like that; the meat is really good.  Yeah, I like that".  This has already gone into my recipe book!

text:
Both my wife and I loved this recipe. I made a few changes: 1 1/2 lbs Stew meat, 1 4oz. can mushrooms (8 oz. fresh next time), 1 whole large onion, 1 1/2 teaspoons garlic (change to two), 1/4 teaspoon paprika,2 tablespoons worchestershire sauce 6 oz. cream cheese, and 1/4 cup water (which is not needed).
Experiment with this recipe it is very flexible and forgiving if you make a mistake. 
ENJOY!!!

text:
Delicious!  Based on other reviews, I doubled the sauce (except for the cream cheese).  I added the cream cheese & some boiled egg noodles about 45 minutes before serving and let it simmer.  I turned off the heat about 15 minutes before serving to let it cool slightly.  This thickens the sauce and improves the flavor (when the food is too hot we can't taste the flavors).  This is a keeper.  Thanks for the recipe!

text:
I make this recipe often but with a few changes.  To make the sauce go a bit further for my family of 6, I stir in 3 heaping tbsps of flour into the beef before adding the remainder of the ingredients into the crockpot.  Then I add 1 1/2 cups of beef broth rather than 1/4 cup of water and I add 1 minced clove of garlic.  The rest is the same.  This is a family favourite :-)!

So easy and yummy - what a treat to have this waiting for you at the end of the day!  The cream cheese was a lovely change of pace, and was definitely not overwhelmingly rich.  Two days later, I microwaved the leftovers for lunch and it lost some of it's flavor and texture.  So, try to eat it all on the day you make it for maximum tastiness.

text:
Wow, this was so easy and so good! The recipe is great the way it is, though I made just a few modifications.  I lightly browned the meat, just before adding to the pot(for a min or two).  Also, I used a lit less then 4oz of cream cheese and added about 2 tbsp of Sour Cream.  Lastly I added just a tad more water, as mine was a little too thick (perhaps from having to cook it on high, due to lack of time) and added a few dashes of salt and pepper before serving over egg noodles.  This is now apart of my family’s favorite recipe box.  Thanks Jessica!

text:
This is a wonderful recipe. My husband also raved about it, asking for leftovers the next night. I did make a few changes. I added 1/8 teaspoon garlic powder, 1/8 teaspoon fresh ground pepper, and one can of mushrooms. I also cooked it in a skillet instead of the slow cooker. I sauteed the meat, onion, Worcestershire, water, garlic, pepper, and mushrooms. Then, I added the mushroom soup and cooked on low for about 10 minutes. Lastly, I added the cream cheese and let simmer until mixed well.

This recipe was very quick and easy.  I didn't have as much time as I liked for the crock pot, so I browned the meat before putting it in.  I also thought it needed something (after tasting,) so I added a half a package of onion soup mix, garlic and black pepper. text:
Strogonoff-esque. Certainly easy and palatable, but this is not beef strogonoff. I think that while cream cheese makes a creamy and smooth sauce, it misses the tang of sour cream. I tried adding lemon juice but didn't quite punch it up.  I added fresh garlic and portabello mushrooms. What you gain in quick and easy (slow-cooker method), you lose in authenticity. Everything is life has a trade off.

I had almost 2 lbs of meat so I used two cans of soup - one was condensed french onion and the other was "beefy mushroom" (I have never been able to find golden mushroom where I live). I also added about a dozen fresh mushroom slices.  The taste was great, but I had way too much sauce.  I don't know what to do about that because I still want the taste of both soups. Anyway, this a quick, easy, still tasty recipe - my favorite.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
When I saw this recipe I figured it was *safe* enough to try on my 4 kids, 3 with sensory issues and they are VERY PICKY.

I didn't bring the actual recipe to the store with me and ended up using seasoned ground meat in garlic pepper and onion, 16 ounces of corkscrew noodles, a big can of chicken broth, a can of cream of chicken and one can of cream of muchroom and about 1 cp of water. I let this cook on low for about 5 hours, stirring occasionally, at the end I stirred in the cream cheese and about 2 TBS of the worcestershire sauce. ALL my kids ate it!! The way I made it, I would not leave on the stove all day, might get gooey. But even the next day, the noodles did not suck up all the juice and there were no leftovers! I think the cream cheese is a great idea, and it gave it just the right amount of punch. Thank you for the easy meal that EVERYONE ate! ...that has NEVER happened before:)PS... I think if I make this again, I will saute some more onions and mushrooms to put on top..too much flavor for the kids, but perfect for us.

text:
I also dredged the meat in flour and some seasoning and browned it before adding to the crock pot.  This made for a nice, thick sauce in the end.  I also added white cooking wine instead of the water and added fresh mushrooms right in the beginning.  I thought this tasted more like beef stew (minus the veggies) than beef stroganoff.  We thought it was okay but thought it was better after I added the traditional sour cream.  Overall, my husband and I like my other recipe much better which is a stovetop method and partially consists of cream of mushroom soup, sliced sirloin, sour cream, etc.  I hope to post it within the next couple of days for anyone intersted.
